CatDescriptText: Joyce Nolen, housewife, North Side, was part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, April 22, 1961, pg. A1  with question: "Do you think that Negroes, when unable to obtain a 'square deal,' in politics, should register a 'protest' vote by voting for Negro candidates on a ticket, or should they utilize other tactics to protest and continue to vote for all candidates who are qualified and will serve their interests best?" answer reads: "I think we should study the candidate and vote for the best qualified, and if he doesn't look out for our best interests, we should take other action."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Joyce Nolen wearing two toned head scarf and coat, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Thrift Drugs in background, corner of Liberty and Fifth Avenues, Downtown; Portrait of man wearing moustache, light colored shirt, necktie with embroidered design, and jacket with lapel pin and light colored handkerchief in left breast pocket, posed in front of light colored wall
